claim: An ammonia fighting cleaner is good for pet owners.

supporting.text: Ammonia-based cleaners are effective at breaking down organic stains and odors, which are common in households with pets.

attacks.text: Ammonia-based cleaners are effective at breaking down organic stains and odors, which are common in households with pets.
Ammonia fumes are toxic to pets, especially birds and small animals, and can cause respiratory distress.
Proper ventilation and dilution can mitigate ammonia's toxicity, making it safe for use around pets.
Many pet owners prefer enzyme-based cleaners, which are equally effective and non-toxic to pets.
Enzyme cleaners can be more expensive and slower-acting than ammonia-based cleaners.

supporting.text: Many ammonia-based cleaners are formulated to be safe for use around pets when used as directed, providing a balance between effectiveness and safety.

attacks.text: Many ammonia-based cleaners are formulated to be safe for use around pets when used as directed, providing a balance between effectiveness and safety.
Ammonia fumes can still irritate pets' respiratory systems, even when used as directed, especially for animals with pre-existing conditions.
Veterinary studies show that repeated exposure to even low concentrations of ammonia can cause chronic respiratory issues in pets over time.
Many pet owners don't follow dilution instructions precisely, increasing the risk of harm to pets.
Product testing shows most consumers use cleaners at 2-3x the recommended concentration when not using measuring tools.
There are more effective pet-safe cleaners available that don't rely on ammonia at all.
Enzyme-based cleaners have been shown to be 40% more effective at odor removal than ammonia-based ones in controlled tests.

supporting.text: Ammonia is a common ingredient in cleaners designed for pet-related messes, such as urine, due to its ability to neutralize strong odors.

attacks.text: Ammonia is a common ingredient in cleaners designed for pet-related messes, such as urine, due to its ability to neutralize strong odors.
Ammonia can be harmful to pets if inhaled or ingested, potentially causing respiratory issues or poisoning.
Many ammonia-based cleaners are formulated to be pet-safe when used as directed, minimizing health risks.
Ammonia's odor can attract pets to re-soil the same area, counteracting its cleaning benefits.
Proper cleaning techniques, like thorough rinsing, can prevent pets from being attracted to ammonia residues.

supporting.text: Pet owners often prefer ammonia-based cleaners because they are readily available and cost-effective compared to specialized pet-safe alternatives.

attacks.text: Pet owners often prefer ammonia-based cleaners because they are readily available and cost-effective compared to specialized pet-safe alternatives.
Ammonia is toxic to pets and can cause respiratory issues or poisoning if ingested or inhaled.
Many pet owners are unaware of ammonia's toxicity, so their preference does not equate to safety.
Specialized pet-safe cleaners are becoming more affordable and widely available, reducing the cost advantage of ammonia-based cleaners.
Even with increased availability, ammonia-based cleaners still dominate shelf space in many stores, making them more convenient.
The long-term health risks to pets from ammonia exposure outweigh any short-term cost savings.

supporting.text: Ammonia's disinfectant properties help reduce the risk of bacterial contamination from pet waste, promoting a healthier environment for both pets and owners.

attacks.text: Ammonia's disinfectant properties help reduce the risk of bacterial contamination from pet waste, promoting a healthier environment for both pets and owners.
Ammonia fumes can be harmful to pets, especially birds and small animals, causing respiratory distress or other health issues.
Proper ventilation and diluted ammonia use can mitigate respiratory risks while retaining disinfectant benefits.
Many pet-safe enzymatic cleaners are equally effective at disinfecting without the toxicity risks of ammonia.
